title: ConsortiumMetabolism Class
text: ConsortiumMetabolism (MF) objects build backbone ramen functionality providing novel approach representation microbial consortia functional perspective. one three main object types ramen. ConsortiumMetabolism class serves standard way save work data metabolism, function, microbial community.

title: ConsortiumMetabolism Class
text: Upon creation ConsortiumMetabolism class based three column input, additional information calculated: graph representation network MiCo object data different matrices weights graph purely directional, disable calculations bin_mat can define optimised / generalist / robust consortia? metrics object? Tanimoto? MES score (relationship consumption production metabolites) SCS, MUS, MPS, MIP/MRO, SMETANA species metabolites fluxes edges binary matrix flux matrix name flux_consumption flux_production effective_flux_consumption effective_flux_production slots described ConsortiumMetabolism-class() class documentation.

title: ConsortiumMetabolism Class
text: unkown metabolites database ChemmineR 0 fluxes input data correct column names Need function calcs phylo tree metabolites Return output different issues input data

title: ConsortiumMetabolism Class
text: Create unnamed matrix save metabolite names col/row data

title: ConsortiumMetabolism Class
text: getCo(): Returns community tibble format. getSpecies(): Retrieves species community. getMet(): Retrieves metabolites community. getFlux(): Retrieves fluxes community. getEdges(): Retrieves edges community.

title: ConsortiumMetabolism Class
text: create object type MiCo, user must input data listed . data can either contained single tibble data frame, saved CSV file, input separate vectors. species: character vector specifying species present community. met: character vector specifying metabolites present community. flux: numeric vector specifying fluxes metabolite community. name: Character string giving name community. ramen provides function syn_community() generate random MiCo objects based user parameters.
code: data <- tibble::tibble(   species = c(     "RQR9693L",     "RQR9693L",     "RQR9693L",     "RQR9693L",     "MEV1152G",     "MEV1152G",     "MEV1152G",     "XIQ2234Q",     "XIQ2234Q",     "XIQ2234Q"   ),   met = c(     "met3",     "met1",     "met4",     "met4",     "met3",     "met2",     "met2",     "met3",     "met4",     "met1"   ),   flux = c(     -0.3023640,     0.5344641,     -2.2337716,     3.3063823,     2.5520278,     0.3388498,     -1.8460633,     -1.3043675,     -0.4788769,     0.6027292   ) )  # ConsortiumMetabolism(data, name = "example_MiCo") # makeSynMiCo(n_species = 8, max_met = 10, name = "example_syn_MiCo")

what: Create a MiCo Object from a tibble
title: ConsortiumMetabolism Class
text: ramen contains set example data can used analysis microbial communities. example, use data created MiSoS(oup). Two example communities provided package ac_A1R12_1 cit_A1R12_1. MiCo function can take either path .csv file data frame/tibble input.

title: ConsortiumMetabolismAlignment Class
text: Clarify Alignment represented primarily. also TSE object? use assays store alignment, allow quick calculation depth breadth well. Decide metrics include alignment many communities given species? go multiscale entropy? maximise community overlap alignment? happens completley disconnected grpahs? align without gaps? extent alignment interactive? Takes number ConsortiumMetabolism objects input (? list …) additional argument specify pairwise alignment communities desired. default align communities pairwise = TRUE unique pairwise combinations aligned. alignment calculated upon creation object calculated demand?

title: ConsortiumMetabolismAlignment Class
text: variety methods can called ConsortiumMetabolismAlignment object. output methods assigned back variable containing object persist. clusterAlignment: Takes ConsortiumMetabolismAlignment object input additional argument specify clustering algorithm used, works ConsortiumMetabolismAlignment objects undergone pairwise alignment.

title: ConsortiumMetabolismAlignment Class
text: value gives scalar value represent identity two communities. α∑=1n(∑Ci−α)+α \frac{\alpha}{\sum\limits_{= 1}^{n}(\sum C_i - \alpha) + \alpha}

title: ConsortiumMetabolismAlignment Class
text: Communities hash/list containing ConsortiumMetabolism objects overall alignment matrix (binary) alignment matrix longest connected components level score alignments communities highly? figure connecctedness parts alignment whicch less communities represented overall alignment?

title: ConsortiumMetabolismSet
text: MFS can created uniting number MF objects together calling ConsortiumMetabolismSet() MFS() either list MF objects inidividual MF objects. process self trigger processing data, thing happens metadata MFS calculated UUID generated. upon creation, mode alignment already known can supplied constructor function MF follows: ConsortiumMetabolismSet(…, alignment=“multiple”)

title: ConsortiumMetabolismSet
text: Inherit MF class methods Write removeMF() addMF() functions

title: Data Visualisation
code: # # Plots a directed network # plot(cm1) # # Plot the number of species in edges # plot(cm1, type = "nEdges") # # Plot the total consumption fluxes in a network # plot(cm1, type = "Consumption") # # Plot the total production fluxes in a network # plot(cm1, type = "Production") # # Plot the effective consumption fluxes in a network # plot(cm1, type = "EffectiveConsumption") # # Plot the effective production fluxes in a network # plot(cm1, type = "EffectiveProduction")

what: Functional Microbiome Representation based on TreeSummarizedExperiment — ConsortiumMetabolism
title: Functional Microbiome Representation based on TreeSummarizedExperiment — ConsortiumMetabolism
text: Creates ConsortiumMetabolism object representing metabolic interactions microbial community. object contains information metabolite consumption production different species, along various metrics like flux sums effective fluxes.

code: ConsortiumMetabolism(   data,   name = NA_character_,   species_col = "species",   metabolite_col = "met",   flux_col = "flux",   ... )

title: Functional Microbiome Representation based on TreeSummarizedExperiment — ConsortiumMetabolism
text: data DataFrame-like object includes columns specifying species, metabolites fluxes microbiome. fluxes can either weighted unweighted (magnitude 1). name character scalar specifying name Microbiome species_col Character scalar specifying name species column, defaults 'species'. metabolite_col Character scalar specifying name metabolite column, defaults 'met'. flux_col Character scalar specifying name flux column, defaults 'flux'. ... Additional arguments passed constructor.

title: Functional Microbiome Representation based on TreeSummarizedExperiment — ConsortiumMetabolism

title: Compare Species — compareSpecies
text: Compares metabolisms two species outputs list tibbles, containing tibbles intersection, unique, consistency. name suggests, intersection, unique contain intersection unique pathways per species compared, consistency tibble contains information whether specie's set pathways consistent consortia present . species contain edges consortia appear, tibble returned 0 rows. title: Get Edges From a ConsortiumMetabolism Object — getEdges
code: getEdges(object, ...)  # S4 method for class 'ConsortiumMetabolism' getEdges(object)  # S4 method for class 'ConsortiumMetabolismSet' getEdges(   object,   type = c("all", "pan-cons", "niche", "core", "aux"),   quantileCutoff = 0.1 )

title: Get Edges From a ConsortiumMetabolism Object — getEdges
text: object ConsortiumMetabolism ConsortiumMetabolismSet object ... Object-specific arguments. See methods details. type Character scalar giving type edges output. quantileCutoff Numeric scalar 0 1 giving quantile threshold use filtering edges. "pan-cons" "core" types, edges 1 - quantileCutoff returned. "niche" "aux" types, edges quantileCutoff returned. Defaults 0.1 (.e., top/bottom 10\ tibble containing edge information including: consumed/produced metabolites number species involved consumption/production sums effective consumption/production metrics - Returns edges pan-cons - Returns edges present consortia (top 1 - quantileCutoff fraction) niche - Returns rare edges (bottom quantileCutoff fraction consortia) core - Returns edges involving many species (top 1 - quantileCutoff fraction) aux - Returns edges involving species (bottom quantileCutoff fraction) getEdges(ConsortiumMetabolism): Get Edges ConsortiumMetabolism Object getEdges(ConsortiumMetabolismSet): Get Edges ConsortiumMetabolismSet Object

title: Get Functional Groups — getFunctionalGroups
text: Calculates returns functional groups based metabolic reactions. ConsortiumMetabolismSet objects, involves analyzing shared reactions across species identify clusters species similar metabolic capabilities.

text: object ConsortiumMetabolismSet object. k integer scalar specifying number clusters color dendrogram. ... Additional arguments passed specific methods. label_size Numeric scalar specifying label size output plot. label_colours NULL, tb two columns, label colour.

title: Get Functional Groups — getFunctionalGroups
text: dendrogram object representing hierarchical clustering species functional groups. plot dendrogram also displayed.

title: Get Functional Groups — getFunctionalGroups
text: method currently implemented ConsortiumMetabolismSet objects. Future versions extend functionality ConsortiumMetabolismAlignment objects allow comparative functional group analysis across different alignments.

title: Return Species in a Consortium — getSpecies
code: getSpecies(object, ...)  # S4 method for class 'ConsortiumMetabolism' getSpecies(object)  # S4 method for class 'ConsortiumMetabolismSet' getSpecies(   object,   type = c("all", "generalists", "specialists"),   quantileCutoff = 0.15 )  # S4 method for class 'ConsortiumMetabolismAlignment' getSpecies(object)

title: Return Species in a Consortium — getSpecies
text: object ConsortiumMetabolismAlignment Object ... Object-specific arguments. See methods details. type Character scalar giving type species output. quantileCutoff Numeric scalar 0 1 specifying fraction species return type "generalists" "specialists". "generalists", top quantileCutoff fraction species edges returned. "specialists", bottom quantileCutoff fraction fewest edges returned. Defaults 0.15 (.e., 15\ ConsortiumMetabolism objects, character vector species names. ConsortiumMetabolismSet objects, tibble columns species n_edges.character vector representing microorganisms.tibble columns species n_edges.character vector representing microorganisms.   Retrieves species information consortium metabolism objects. ConsortiumMetabolismSet objects, species can filtered metabolic versatility.   ConsortiumMetabolismSet objects, type parameter allows filtering species metabolic characteristics: - Returns species edge counts generalists - Returns species metabolic edges (top quantileCutoff fraction) specialists - Returns species fewest metabolic edges (bottom quantileCutoff fraction) getSpecies(ConsortiumMetabolism): Return Species Microbiome getSpecies(ConsortiumMetabolismSet): Return Species Microbiome getSpecies(ConsortiumMetabolismAlignment): Return Species Microbiome

title: Pivot ConsortiaMetabolism Input Data — pivotCM
code: tb <- tibble::tribble(   ~uptake, ~secretion, ~flux, ~species,   "m1", "m2", 1, "s1",   "m2", "m3", 1, "s2",   "m3", "m4", 1, "s3",   "m4", "m1", 1, "s4" )  pivotCM(   tb = tb,   species = "species",   from = "uptake",   to = "secretion",   flux = "flux" ) #> # A tibble: 8 × 3 #>   species met    flux #>   <chr>   <chr> <dbl> #> 1 s1      m1       -1 #> 2 s1      m2        1 #> 3 s2      m2       -1 #> 4 s2      m3        1 #> 5 s3      m3       -1 #> 6 s3      m4        1 #> 7 s4      m4       -1 #> 8 s4      m1        1

what: Plot a Directed Graph Emphasizing Flow — plotDirectedFlow
title: Plot a Directed Graph Emphasizing Flow — plotDirectedFlow
text: Arranges nodes directed graph three distinct columns representing sources (nodes outgoing edges), sinks (nodes incoming edges), intermediate nodes (incoming outgoing edges). layout within intermediate column determined using Fruchterman-Reingold algorithm. visualization helps understand overall flow structure within graph.

title: Plot a Directed Graph Emphasizing Flow — plotDirectedFlow
code: plotDirectedFlow(   g,   source_x = 0,   mixed_x = 1,   sink_x = 2,   vertical_spacing = 1,   vertex_size = 10,   vertex_label_cex = 0.8,   edge_arrow_size = 0.5,   edge_width_range = c(0.1, 0.1),   color_edges_by_weight = FALSE,   edge_color_low = "gray80",   edge_color_high = "black",   ... )

title: Plot a Directed Graph Emphasizing Flow — plotDirectedFlow
text: g igraph object. Must directed graph. source_x Numeric scalar. x-coordinate source nodes. Defaults 0. mixed_x Numeric scalar. central x-coordinate intermediate nodes. actual layout spans mixed_x +/- 0.4. Defaults 1. sink_x Numeric scalar. x-coordinate sink nodes. Defaults 2. vertical_spacing Numeric scalar. maximum y-coordinate, controlling vertical spread layout. Defaults 1. vertex_size Numeric scalar. size vertices (nodes) plot. Defaults 10. vertex_label_cex Numeric scalar. character expansion factor vertex labels. Defaults 0.8. edge_arrow_size Numeric scalar. size arrows edges. Defaults 0.5. edge_width_range Numeric vector length 2. minimum maximum width edges scaled weight. graph unweighted weights identical, mean range used. Defaults c(0.1, 0.1). color_edges_by_weight Logical scalar. TRUE graph 'weight' edge attribute, edges colored based weight, interpolating edge_color_low edge_color_high. edge_color_low Character string. color lowest edge weight color_edges_by_weight TRUE. Defaults "gray80". edge_color_high Character string. color highest edge weight color_edges_by_weight TRUE. Defaults "black". ... Additional arguments passed igraph.

title: Plot a Directed Graph Emphasizing Flow — plotDirectedFlow
text: Invisibly returns NULL. function called side effect generating plot.
